data.title: After years away from the musical spotlight, Aly and AJ reclaim their base
data.meta_description: Alyson and Amanda Michalka, a.k.a. Aly an AJ, began their singing career almost simultaneously with their acting career
data.text:
Reviews and recommendations are unbiased and products are independently selected. Postmedia may earn an affiliate commission from purchases made through links on this page.

Article content

Aly and AJ

When: June 18 at 8:30 p.m.

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Try refreshing your browser, or

tap here to see other videos from our team.

After years away from the musical spotlight, Aly and AJ reclaim their base Back to video

Where: Commodore Ballroom

Tickets: $36 at ticketmaster.ca

Alyson and Amanda Michalka, a.k.a. Aly and AJ, began their singing career almost simultaneously with their acting career. But music took a back seat for several years, and it wasn’t until 2017 that they re-emerged with an EP, Ten Years. Judging by the pre-show chanting that goes on during their current tour, the duo has managed to keep some of those early fans.

Article content

“It doesn’t happen everyday, like when we’re just walking down a hallway, but we do get quite a lot of chanting at our shows, which is very fun,” said Aly. “A lot of fans that have stuck with us over the years, who were super-patient about us coming back with new music. And we’ve gained some new fans who were introduced to us through Ten Years.”

Raised in Torrance, California, the sisters started their show business careers with Disney. Aly was first, getting a role in 2004 in the show Phil of the Future, but in 2006 both appeared in the Disney Channel original movie Cow Belles.

Meanwhile, the pop duo signed to the entertainment company’s Hollywood Records label and released their debut album, Into the Rush, in 2005. The success of that album (certified gold in the U.S.) led to two more for Hollywood, including 2007’s Insomniatic, before they left the label. They pursued their acting careers, with Aly starring for five seasons in the now-defunct shot-in-Vancouver series iZombie, while AJ appeared in the ABC sitcom The Goldbergs. During that period they released a single and flirted with a name change (78violet) but it wasn’t until 2017 that Aly and AJ re-emerged with the self-released Ten Years.

Article content

“We stayed engaged with our fanbase, and we were in the public eye because of our acting careers,” AJ said, explaining their connection to early admirers.

“I think our fans ended up seeing that we released new music and thought, ‘Wow, I grew up with this material for so many years, it’s my duty to embrace this act again.’ They stuck with us for that long and we can’t thank them enough.”

Their latest release is another EP, Sanctuary. Released in May, it features eighties-inspired synth-pop tracks like Church (the first single) and Don’t Go Changing, and represents an evolution in the group’s lyrical concerns.

“It was really important to create a body of work that felt different from what we released last year,” AJ said. “So much of what we hear on the radio is about makeups and breakups and everything in between. It was time for us to depart from relationship albums and make something more reflective. The Sanctuary EP has hit a new level of depth with our fans that I think they needed to hear.”

“Ultimately at the end of the day AJ and I just wanted to connect with our fans on a personal level,” Aly said. “Songs like Sanctuary and Church are incredibly personal to us, and I know our fans look at those songs as mini-anthems for themselves. We didn’t want to waiver too far that we had created on Ten Years, but we also knew we wanted to create something different. It wasn’t just, Let’s put out our five favourite songs or five hookiest songs. They were intentional in subject matter as well.”

Naturally, their next move is to make another full-length album.

Alyson and Amanda Michalka, a.k.a. Aly an AJ, began their singing career almost simultaneously with their acting career. But music took a back seat for several years, and it wasn’t until 2017 that they re-emerged with an EP, Ten Years. Judging by the pre-show chanting that goes on, the duo managed to keep some of those early fans.

“It doesn’t happen everyday, like when we’re just walking down a hallway, but we do get quite a lot of chanting at our shows, which is very fun,” said Aly. “A lot of fans that have stuck with us over the years, who were super-patient about us coming back with new music. And we’ve gained some new fans who were introduced to us through our Ten Years EP.”

Raised in Torrance, California, the sisters started their show business careers with Disney. Aly was first, getting a role in 2004 in the Disney Channel show Phil of the Future, but in 2006 both appeared in the Disney Channel original movie Cow Belles.

Meanwhile, the pop duo signed to the entertainment company’s Hollywood Records label and released their debut album, Into the Rush, in 2005. The success of that album (certified gold in the U.S.) led to two more for Hollywood, including 2007’s Insomniatic, before the two left the label. They pursued their acting careers, with Aly starring for five seasons in the now-defunct shot-in-Vancouver series iZombie, while AJ was in the sitcom The Goldbergs. During that time they released a single and flirted with a name change (78violet) but it wasn’t until 2017 that Aly and AJ re-emerged with the self-released Ten Years.

“We stayed engaged with our fanbase, and we were in the public eye because of our acting careers,” AJ said, explaining their connection to early admirers.

“I think our fans ended up seeing that we released new music and thought, ‘Wow, I grew up with this material for so many years, it’s my duty to embrace this act again.’ They stuck with us for that long and we can’t thank them enough. And we grew a brand new fan base.”

Their latest release is another EP, Sanctuary. Released in May, it features eighties-inspired synth-pop tracks like Church (the first single) and Don’t Go Changing, and represents and evolution in the group’s lyrical concerns.

“It was really important to create a body of work that felt different from what we released last year,” AJ said. “So much of what we hear on the radio is about makeups and breakups and everything in between. It was time for us to depart from relationship albums and make something more reflective. The Sanctuary EP has hit a new level of depth with our fans that I think they needed to hear.”

“Ultimately at the end of the day AJ and I just wanted to connect with our fans on a very personal level,” Aly said. “Songs like Sanctuary and Church are incredibly personal to us, and I know our fans look at those songs as mini-anthems for themselves. The fact that we were able to make a second EP that felt cohesive from our first was important. We didn’t want to waiver too far that we had created on Ten Years, but we also knew we wanted to create something different. It wasn’t just put out our five favourite songs or five hookiest songs. They were intentional in subject matter as well.”

Naturally, their next move is to make another full-length album. “People take things really well in small doses,” Aly said. “After taking such a long break we’ve given them a collection of six songs here, five songs there. And now it’s time to open up the scope a little wider.”
